reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am a fan of this game already. But i will try and keep this review un-biased as i can...

I think first you need to understand something about this game. This is not just a puzzle game. I can imagine the developers had a hard time deciding what they would describe this as, genre wise. And how to market a game on Steam that is more than a computer game.

Because thats what you have here. Something that breaks down the fourth wall. Not break through, it gets rid of it. you step off the stage as a person, as you. Or at least you if you were in a different reality. Its a game that expects you to put some real work into it. By using real life resources such as search engines, and even websites generated for the game. real websites. Not websites shown by some in-game UI. A real website that you access through your browser of choice.
This game asks you bring skills to it or at least learn them.
There is even an aspect (which is optional. See below) that requires you to get out of your chair and head into the world.

Lets look at that last aspect for a moment. As it is probably the only one i can see being somewhat controversial. There is an aspect to this game that seeks to turn it into a LARP (Live Action Role-Play) like experience. Understand that it is optional. But it is where this becomes a hobby in itself rather than just a game.
You may, if you so wish, provide your phone/mobile/cell number. And if you wish to go one step further, your address. By doing this you are immersing yourself in the game world. You can receive phone calls giving you clues to new or existing mysteries. Or a package in the mail that holds some object that is part of a current mystery or is something new. All in the style of an X-files like conspiracy theory narrative.

And this game does have a narrative of sorts. As i stated it is a little like a LARP. There is an on-going player driven story. What you and others as players do in the game world has consequence. It affects what happens next.

Community is a very big part of this game. Whether you go the full immersion route or not. You all play as a group working together towards a common goal.

I feel this is a game that needs to be experienced to truly appreciate what it is. I just found a new hobby. And all I did was buy an Early Access game. I or anyone else can try and describe this until blue in the face. But I don’t think it can be described. Words don’t do this game justice.

Anyway, this review is long enough.

Look, the small answer to whether you should get this is simple:
If you read the description, watched the trailers, and found you were intrigued. I say give it a shot. At worst you will play through the first episode, get some entertainment through the puzzles and then move on. At best; you will be hooked. And you will participate in something you most likely have never experienced that is a work of genius. Something that, as a gamer, you will have fond memories of in the future.

I hope to see you in-game.

reviewText:
An extremely interesting game for those of you who like to research and play a game in the real world. It's a Permanent Alternate Reality game - meaning that to advance in the game, you have to do things that require you to do it on the internet, or even, if you're brave, in real life. You have to use your brain, social engineering and research. You learn many things on the way - it's extremely fun, I just planned a Mission Impossible infiltration yesterday.

It's also very spooky since it includes secret organizations such as the Knights Templar or Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn. You sometimes have to infiltrate and decode the things sent to them/by them - and it somehow manages to make you feel as if you were actually doing it - extremely realistic.

If you do decide to buy the game, never look at the things you see in the game generally. They all often require thinking outside of the box and you have to brainstorm to find out what they mean. Tell me if you decide to play - I've finished the game all by myself in twelve hours. I'll help you out.

If you buy it now until the end of the September, you'll get Season Two for free. I highly recommend it.

EDIT1: The game doesn't end when you finish the missions it throws at you. I just received emails with even more things to decode and research - it's going to be a long-term relationship between me and this game. If you finish it like me, look at your email - there's bound to be something there from Division 66 that requires you and your skills.

Early Access Review

Having previously played Majestic back in 2000 I was really excited by the prospect of playing a similar ARG.  Unfortunately, The Black Watchmen disappoints.

With Majestic, the game drew you in with phone calls, faxes, and emails.  Fake websites were created and false news stories were inserted into reputable news sites like CNN via the client software.  The game was an immersive experience.  Characters in the game would frantically call you with secret messages or informing you that their cover had been breached.  This is how the game made all the research fun.

The Black Watchmen fails to engage.  I've now completed 11 missions and I am not sure if I am interested in playing further.  I'm definately not engaged and while there are some very friendly, helpful people in the forums the promise of the game requiring cooperative effort from the agents is only true because the missions are so badly written that it takes a community to figure out exactly what the game wants.

To me, this is a huge disappointment.  The story is unimmaginative and the gameplay is unengaging.  The community is for the most part unintersted in working together outside of the forum which would have made the game much more engaging.  I don't want to go into details about what the story is about for fear of spoiling it for someone but just think an episode of X-Files you've seen a dozen times.  As far as the gameplay, the only elements of the story that are woven into the gameplay are those directly related to a go here and do this" sort of thing meaning there's never a joy of discovery. reviewText:
Now that the first “season” of the game has ended and Early Access is over, I think I can give a more wholesome review of this game.

Firstly, I wrote a guide to navigating this game. If you want to know what an ARG is, look at the first part:

http://steamcommunity.com/id/riningear/recommended/349220

Tl;dr it's a puzzle game with some online-RP/LARP aspects.

Let me make this clear right now: No. It’s not for everyone. I really do respect that. Especially with the “Live Missions” aspect -- some of the stuff is time-sensitive, and it can be a lot to keep up with. That’s part of an Alternate Reality Game like this. And not everyone wants to opt into receiving phone calls and/or packages. That’s really fine, but I understand it can leave some players feeling just a bit underwhelmed by the content because of their lack of choice to do so. (If you opt out, you’re not useless -- you can help those players figure out the puzzles. It really does help.)

If you want to get a feel for what's going on, download the demo, chat with the community in the IRC (there's a guide to that in the guide I linked), and poke around the game's forums to check out the gameplay that's happened.

With that said, if you do choose to play this game, there’s a lot of considerations to be made.

Someone I’m friends with at school saw me playing this and asked: “Why Steam?” I think that’s an important question. This is really the first major, recent attempt at a business model for an Alternate Reality Game. ARGs are usually constructed by third parties as promotions for existing or upcoming products -- Ingress, for example, has an Alternate-Reality platform to support its Augmented-Reality platform. In fact, The Black Watchmen is the direct product of The Secret World’s ARG promotions, run by the same company.

With that said, as someone who joined in during the Kickstarter, reaching out to a broader audience and trying to pull people into a niche from the mainstream definitely is a challenge. I think that’s where I saw a bit of a struggle with the devs, especially with “live” missions. It’s easy to come from a background of appealing to more hardcore ARG players and later have issues trying to ease into something more palatable.

That’s where we get into something that could have easily made or broken this game -- the devs. I literally cannot have enough praise for them. While many ARGs attempt not to break the fourth wall in helping its players, there’s a mutual understanding between the devs and the players that this is a new exploration of the genre, a real attempt to make something bigger out of what’s been a niche genre. So there’s been a lot of conversation between the players and devs, and I really appreciate that, as both a player and an “investor” (I mean, it was only $25, but I didn’t have much at the time…).

It really showed in the final “live” mission. All the complaints and criticisms led up to a very involved, very well-thought-out kind of experience that roped in a lot of players. I had my own personal approach to it, but I had no time to manage everyone, and so they did it on their own to great success.

I guess that’s something else that’s kept me in: the community. A strong backbone to an ARG is its community, and this community has always been really warm and welcoming to new players. I had to squeeze in back during a much more difficult mission during the Kickstarter, but now it’s certainly opened up nicely. It’s something you have to get involved in to believe.

For those of you wondering about the gameplay and puzzles… unless you’re a savant of some kind, you definitely need help on some of these missions. But that’s fine. In fact, the devs encourage it. And these missions are immersive and exciting, especially towards the end, and even if I didn’t have live missions available, the $35 I would have spent (soon $15 for this season after the sale/month ends) would have likely been worth it to more intense puzzle fans. (Though in a market of $10 puzzle games… eh.)

But some of these puzzles that dig deep into the oddest parts of your knowledge and trivia, and your Google search skills. It’s pretty cool. I definitely recommend at least working through the puzzles if you want to try “something else.” Once you get to know that little noise effect from a successful answer, it'll be your best friend and the warmest feeling in the world.

The client’s odd and bulky in some parts and we’re trying to exchange feedback about it. A lot of it's left over from the beta versions. But you won't be using it that much anyway, given the game involved a lot of real-world research.

Summary: Great puzzles, great people. Definitely invest if you want to be a part of something new and exciting. But it’s not for everyone -- try the demo, check the IRC, get a feel for it.

Just don’t be rude if it isn’t for you. A lot of the negative reviews are often because people are uncomfortable about the game’s aspects. Don’t fall into that trap -- figure it out for yourself.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A Weekend With The Black Watchmen ARG

The world is overflowing with mysteries and conspiracy; some are visible to all, but others are less obvious, hidden beneath a layer of secrecy, lies and the occult. If you go deep enough down the rabbit hole you are bound to discover some disturbing things – things almost too plausible to be true. Blood rituals, human sacrifice and experimentation are mainstays of the silver screen, there’s no way that they could be taking place beneath our very noses, or could they? There are agents worldwide investigating these disturbing reports and this weekend I joined them to get to the bottom of some shadowy people and their dealings. This is how I became a member of The Black Watchmen.

I initially mistook The Black Watchmen as just a game, but it is much more than that. I am now part of a secret reconnaissance cell partaking in undercover investigations. My basic training involved learning to crack codes – binary, hexadecimal and rot13 enciphered messages – a cinch given my degree in computer science, but things soon became more difficult. My fellow agents and I were tasked with investigating the disappearance of an antique collector – and that’s when things took a decidedly more sinister turn. The case files we were given, drafted by the first agent on the scene, consisted of nothing but seemingly innocuous images of books, dolls, crucifixes and bottles. The keen-eyed among us were able to identify a rot13 enciphered code in one of the images, which we were then able to decipher manually. The code pointed towards a pastebin link with details of an antique script called “Folio 13″, the kind a collector would love to have in their collection, but how did it tie in with his disappearance?

A Google search for “folio 13″ and “Cipher MMS” lead me down a rabbit hole of religion, conspiracy, secret societies and the occult. I was suddenly in over my head, reading up on ancient Jewish sects and Pope John Paul’s teachings – certainly nothing that could be attributed to the disappearance. I was over thinking things, going way too deep and missing an answer that was right in front of me. The organisation that penned the document wanted it back and was willing to go to any lengths to get it.

As the case was solved I gave myself a pat on the back and put my feet up, but my respite didn’t last long. The agency had heard word that a clinic tied to rumours of human experimentation had reopened its doors and I had been asked to investigate its staff members for any signs of illegal activity. By cross-referencing each staff member’s employment history I was soon able to establish a link between them and illegal human experiments – all those years of Google-fu were finally becoming useful.

With a link established it was tie to go deeper and find out exactly what was going on at the clinic. An undercover team was dispatched after closure to bug the building for remote monitoring. And then silence. The agency ceased contact until Sunday when all agents abruptly received an email informing us that the alert level had been “raised to 3″. With urgency we made our way to our usual channels of communication (IRC) and began to converse about what could be happening, and there it was. In our game clients was an image coded in braille.

The image was surprisingly complex, containing not only the braille code, but a map that could be uncovered by applying various filters, and behind that were words which turned out to be street names. Some very intelligent deciphering later we had uncovered a restaurant in Portland called “The Fried Onion”.  Initial reconnaissance of the location yielded no results, but now as the restaurant opens for business, we have agents on route for a face to face with forces unknown.

Now we wait

What can I say.

I've only had this game a few weeks but I've been sucked into the addicting and immersive world of this game. I was a little reluctant to buy this game at first because I wasn't sure if I wanted to be a part of the ARG aspect of it. The great thing about TBW is that you don't have to do any ARG stuff if you don't want. Even the live missions can be completed without any of the extra stuff. However, now that I've realized how awesome the game is though, I've started to get into the ARG aspect of the game.

Basically there are 5 levels of immersion.

Red: The lowest level of immersion. The only thing required for red is an email.

Orange: This level is a bit more immersive. You have to register your phone number and will sometimes get phone calls/voicemails for live missions.

Yellow: Yellow is the highest level conventionally available. To be a yellow agent you must submit your location and will receive mail and sometimes have to do things in your area.

Green: To be a green agent you must submit a full medical report and do a ton of real world stuff. Only 8 people are selected for green each season.

Black: Classified Info

As you can see, the game gives you a lot of different options to choose from.

Now to the actual game. The game is very addicting and challenging enough to keep you wanting more. You investigate everything from illegal testing to cults to mutants to the apocalypse. The game does a great job of making you feel like you're somewhere you're not supposed to be.

Not only is the game and immersion great, but the community is one of the most welcoming communities I've ever been a part of. You can go to the forums at forums.blackwatchmen.com and the IRC at  https://kiwiirc.com/client/irc.blackwatchmen.com/division66
The vets will always be glad to help if you're stuck on a mission.

Anyway, I love this game. It's addicting, fun, immersive, and has a great community.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm not one to write game reviews usually. This time, I feel strongly enough about this game that I want to spread the word. If you enjoy puzzles, mysteries in the line of X-Files and the MMO The Secret World, and are willing to put yourself into the game, this will be a home run for you.

This ARG uses the real world as the surface with you becoming part of a secret organization who deals with those events outside the realm of the police. As a member of the Black Watchmen, you will work alone and with other agents to solve mysteries through ciphering, internet research and more. The puzzles themselves are great and you really feel an AH-HA moment when you succeed. The community is strong and willing to help. We can't solve everything on our own.

The big selling point for me is the level of immersion. You can play the game without giving any of your information (Red) and still be a part of almost everything. If you are ok giving more personal information, then you become part of the game.  You can get phone calls relating to the game. You can have packages sent to you and even be called upon to go to locations in your area to help in the live events. The potential is huge for this game. The devs have been hands on with the community, quick to answer questions and keep everyone excited about what is on the other side of the rabbit hole.

Some are complaining about the price as it does include the first season (roughly 3 months). This includes not just the game itself, but live events and secret missions. I do feel that you will get your money's worth IF this type of game appeals to you. The more of yourself you are willing to put into it, the more you will get from it.

reviewText:
Well, I came into this expecting something along the lines of 'In Memoriam' (Missing, if you're in the US).
Sort of a follow-the-breadcrumbs style of game using real-world browsers.
And it sort of is.
You're playing as an agent of this undercover agency designed to protect against supernatural (I think) threats.
You get hints and clues, and it's really up to you as to how you go about deciphering them.

So, the good stuf first.
I love the idea. This whole blending of real-world and game is right up my alley.

But that's about it for the good stuff.
On the con-side however.......
The objectives themselves for each chapter are very vague. Add to that, a lot of the clues are bewilderingly worded, so you spend a lot of time either researching things that you don't have to because the answer the game is looking for is right in front of you.
Or, you spend a few hours doing a hunt-the-hidden-answer, as you try to figure out which of the bits of information you have will actually allow you to progress.
If you've ever played some of the old text-based adventure games where you had to find the correct word for the game to trigger correctly, you have an understanding of what is going on in this game.
It doesn't exactly help that the difficulty-level is all over the place.
You jump from dead-easy into a maze of strangely worded questions that absolutely requires prior knowledge to figure out.

And of course, with these types of games comes an inherent shelf-life.
If you happen to buy this game a year from now, is there any guarantee that any of the embedded web-sites needed are still around?

It's a very neat concept, it's just not very well executed.

EDIT: Are you f*cking kidding me?
A puzzle-hint involving a FaceBook account??
Okay, first of all, there is no 'clear link' between the Rosenberg Clinic and Superterram Life Sciences.
One does neurological research, and the other is a body farm.
One is in Montreal, the other in Texas.
There are no documents, mails, telephone-taps or anything else that would make this company any more interesting than any of the others.
The only real link is that it's the only company-name that actually pops up in the search-engines.
That's not deduction, that's just mechanical grinding until you eliminate suspects.
And besides, are you really telling me that we can find a higly classified document re. medical experiments on the intranet, but apart from that we only have a vague browser-history to go on?
That is honestly just bad writing.

Even if I were willing to forgive that, using FB as a part of your game is.....
Well, let me put it this way; if having a FB account is required for completing this game (which it is), I would strongly suggest that you put it on the list of game-requirements, along with processor, GPU and all that.
Had I known it was a pre-requisite, I wouldn't have touched this game with a proverbial ten-foot pole.
And before you say Just use a pseudonym and create a FB account".....
That would violate the ToS of FB
date:
and is technically illegal.

First game I ever bought where I have seriously contemplated going for a refund.
Oh well

reviewText:
The Black Watchmen (TBW) game really hits the mark as a great Alternate Reality Game (ARG): in TBW you play the role of a paranormal investigation agent, fighting demons, witches and black cults around the world.

The TBW agency is powerful and well connected. While playing, you have the chance to exploit many different personal skills, as you work in front of your computer screen (using the game client or accessing the internet as well). In that case, code-breaking knowledge, social media and social engineering skills will be your assets! Many training missions are provided for your preparation as well, and the players' community is very helpful if you are stuck on a single player mission.

Furthermore, you can play with other agents using the game chat assets: you might even have the chance to actually go in field! Depending on your chosen clearance level in the agency, in Real Life you might be asked to analyse objects or document you receive by mail, or to go out in your town delivering documents or, in some cases, to meet actual NPCs, especially in the occasion of the game Live Events that involve collaboration of all TBW agents for a single mission that might go on for some days.
TBW is a great game, I really think that it is worthwhile to give it a try. You will be surprised!
